generif.text: Expression of MRP3 can be induced by certain nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (e.g., indomethacin) in a reactive oxygen species-dependent but cyclooxygenase-2-independent manner.
tissue distribution and induction in normal human tissues and in cholestasis
possible role in the removal of bile acids from the liver in cholestasis
down- and up-regulation of MRP1 (and MRP3) expression can influence cellular folate homeostasis, in particular when cellular retention by polyglutamylation of folates is attenuated.
MRP3 active transport of estradiol-17-beta-d-glucuronide and MRP3 ATPase characteristics in isolated, inside-out membrane vesicles
Genetic polymorphisms in the MRP3 is associated with liver neoplasms
Upregulation of MRP3 expression is associated with pancreatic carcinoma
VDR has a role in the protection of colon cells from bile acid toxicity through regulation of the Mrp3 expression

a polymorphism -211C>T in the promoter region of MRP3 does not determine the expression level of the gene in acute leukemia

Mrp2 and Mrp3 provide alternative routes for the excretion of a glucuronidated substrate from the liver in vivo.

MRP1-Pro(1150), MRP2-Pro(1158), and MRP3-Pro(1147) in the cytoplasmic loop 7 differ in their influence on substrate specificity but share a common role in the nucleotide interactions at nucleotide binding domain 2 of these transporters.

ABCC3 is a mediator of taxane resistance in HER2-amplified breast cancer.
MRP3 could be a novel molecular marker for localized non-mucinous bronchioloalveolar carcinoma, whose expression increases during the early progression of tumourigenesis

MRP3, MRP4, and MRP5 are upregulated in 5-fluorouracil-resistant cells, and MRP5 contributes to 5-FU resistance in pancreatic carcinoma cells.

study identified genetic polymorphisms of ABCC3 and evaluated their effects on ABCC3 expression and MRP3 function; 61 genetic variants were identified in three ethnic populations; of these variants 17 were novel
MRP3 A-189 T polymorphism was associated with treatment responses in acute lymphoblastic leukemia , likely due to the change in MRP3 efflux.

investigation of vectorial transport across enterocytes: Data from Caco-2 cell monolayers, models for intestinal absorption, suggest that MRP3 mediates fexofenadine/zwitterion efflux across basolateral membrane.
Low ABCC3 expression was associated with reduced event-free survival of neuroblastoma patients.

Anti-ABCC3 IgA and IgG were determined using an enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) approach.

human cornea models possessed MRP3 and BCRP expression, whereas no functional expression was found in rabbit and porcine corneas.

Induction of MRP3 expression by 17alpha-ethynylestradiol requires recruitment of estrogen receptor-alpha and activator protein-1.

ABCC3 expression may serve as a marker for MDR and predictor for poor clinical outcome of NSCLC.

variants of ABCB1 rs128503, ABCC3 rs4148416, and GSTP1 rs1695 are associated with response to chemotherapy and survival of osteosarcoma patients
Aberrant expression of MRP3 in rectal cancer confers chemo-radioresistance.

for ABCC3 variants, little evidence, if any, was found for an association of drug response to genetic variants
A functional Nrf2 response element within the eighth intron of the ABCC3 gene.
Epidermal growth factor - mediated epithelial-mesenchymal transition induces ABCC3 mRNA in MDA-MB-468 breast cancer cells. The process is calcium dependant.

Data suggest that hepatic expression of MRP3 is up-regulated and canalicular localization of MRP2 is altered in pediatric patients with advanced nonalcoholic steatohepatitis; these alterations may be involved in changes observed in drug metabolism.
ABCC3 promoter methylation does not seem to exhibit any impact on maximum platelet aggregation and clopidogrel response at all
ABCC3 rs4148416 polymorphism was significantly associated with poor osteosarcoma response.

This report is the first to describe liver overexpression of Abcc3 during the cancer initiation, promotion, and progression periods in rat hepatocarcinogenesis model and in human hepatocellular carcinoma
ABCC3 is an important oncoprotein involved in glycolysis and drug resistance
High MRP expression is associated with sorafenib resistance in hepatocellular carcinoma.
ABCC3 genetic variants are associated with postoperative morphine-induced respiratory depression and morphine pharmacokinetics in children.
This study highlights the importance of ABCC3 transporters in drug resistance to chemotherapy in the context of breast cancer.

PXR is a potential biomarker for predicting outcome and activates MRP3 transcription by directly binding to its promoter resulting in an increased L-OHP efflux capacity, and resistance to L-OHP or platinum drugs in CRC.

miR-148a-siRNA and rifampin inhibited estradiol upregulation of MRP3 expression.  miR-148a may be involved in the estrogen induction in intrahepatic cholestasis of pregnancy via PXR signaling. MRP3 may be involved.
Data show that bladder cancer is associated with perturbed expression of MRP3 and BCRP.
CGI may function as an enhancer of the transcription of ABCC3.
Low expression of MRP3 is associated with Hepatocellular Carcinoma and in Cholangiocarcinoma.

Data suggest that inhibition of sirtuin 1 and sirtuin 2 in hepatocellular carcinoma cells (a) impairs cell survival and cell migration and (b) down-regulates expression of P-glycoprotein and MRP3 (ATP binding cassette subfamily C member 3).

OATPB1/B3 and MRP3 immunohistochemistry and signal intensity on hepatobiliary phase Gd-EOB-DTPA-enhanced MRI can help to stratify hepatocellular adenoma according to their risk of malignant transformation.

The glucuronides of inactive androgens, androsterone glucuronide and etiocholanolone glucuronide were preferentially transported by MRP3, whereas the glucuronides of active androgens, Testosterone glucuronide and dihydrotestosterone glucuronide were mainly transported by MRP2 in liver.

Bile acid and bile salt metabolism

wikipathways.name: Drug Induction of Bile Acid Pathway
Nuclear Receptors in Lipid Metabolism and Toxicity

summary: The protein encoded by this gene is a member of the superfamily of ATP-binding cassette (ABC) transporters. ABC proteins transport various molecules across extra- and intra-cellular membranes. ABC genes are divided into seven distinct subfamilies (ABC1, MDR/TAP, MRP, ALD, OABP, GCN20, White). This protein is a member of the MRP subfamily which is involved in multi-drug resistance. The specific function of this protein has not yet been determined; however, this protein may play a role in the transport of biliary and intestinal excretion of organic anions. Alternatively spliced variants which encode different protein isoforms have been described; however, not all variants have been fully characterized. [provided by RefSeq, Jul 2008].
